But then, with some of these other women jumped in, including Julie Swetnick, who's their subject the first referral from Senator Grassley. I think it muddied the waters because their claims were outlandish, didn't have any backup whatsoever, and now we have the second woman who had been anonymous saying, yes, I made it up. Which sort of plays into what the critics of the -- of the people who are going after Judge Kavanaugh, who were saying, which is you can't necessarily believe anybody who comes out of the woodwork without evidence. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('tablet', 'lb21', 'tablet-tw-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You know, and you had reporters like Jane Mayer -- you know, publishing stories that were not corroborated.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Based on the same sort of situations -- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb13', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb13', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: Julie Swetnick ended up backing off in an NBC interview. She said he spiked the punch, no, I didn't see it. She claimed that she witnessed all these gang rape parties. It simply was incredible. I don't know what will happen or the referral to the Justice Department, but it does show you that in that overheated atmosphere, media in particular and the public and the politicians have been very, very careful about these explosive claims if there's no corroborating evidence.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: He's pursuing it. And it's important, obviously to stick to the facts. Howie, thank you very much. Good to see you tonight.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.sentences: Good to see you here in Washington.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, in Florida, two candidates try to win over Miami voters, where the district is increasingly purple. You've got wealthy neighborhoods, you have many Cuban Americans there. You have a lot of folks who fled New York and New Jersey for the Sunshine State. So, it's a real interesting mix of Florida voters. And it is making for quite a race between Maria Salazar and Donna Shalala, that's coming up next. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb14', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb14', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Hundreds of thousands of children born to illegal immigrants are made automatic citizens of the United States every year because of this crazy lunatic policy that we can end, that we can end.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: President Trump hammering home his opposition to birthright citizenship heading into Tuesday's elections and it is front and center in Florida's hotly contested 27th district. Democrat Donna Shalala is up seven points over Republican Maria Salazar in the latest New York Times poll, but only a few days earlier Salazar led Shalala by two points in a Mason-Dixon poll. So in this heavily Hispanic district, Salazar initially went after the president in this tweet saying this. President Trump, our Constitution is sacred. Birthright citizenship is protected and you cannot change that by executive order. But now says that the 14th Amendment should "be reviewed." Here to tell us about that House Republican candidate Maria Salazar. Good to have you with us this evening. I should mention that we have also reached out to your opponent and we are hopeful that she will join us on Monday evening. But you heard the President, he said this is a crazy lunatic law when he refers to the 14th Amendment. Do you agree with him?

utterances.speaker: MARIA SALAZAR, R, CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE, FLORIDA
utterances.sentences: Well, what I agree is that we need to look for an immigration reform law and that is one of them -- my signature plan. Because look what you were talking about in the previous segment, look at the caravan that is arriving. What are we going to do? We need to and I have called for an immigration reform law but not only that, for a summit meeting where President Trump can really show his leadership, where he should call for a summit meeting between the president of Honduras, El Salvador, and Guatemala and help them keep their boys home. That is the only way my said that is going to prevent another caravan from occurring. Because as you were saying before, the Honduras is one of the most explosive countries in the hemisphere. It has one of the highest murder rates in the world. So what do you think those people are going to do? And I'm not saying that we need to allow them in, I'm not saying that we cannot protect or we should not protect our borders, what I'm saying is that we need to find a solution. And since I am from Miami, and we have hundreds of thousands of undocumented aliens in my town, and I know them very well, I know what the solution is. At one point I was the Central American Bureau Chief for Univision. I lived in Guatemala, I lived in El Salvador, in Nicaragua, and in Honduras, and I know what they need. And I saw President Reagan showing leadership in helping those people, in helping their governments to have to keep their boys home. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Understood. You know, when you look at your district though, and you know, I mean, people have been trying to do what you're suggesting and come up with comprehensive immigration reform for decades and I think it's one of the greatest frustrations that the American people have because both sides just like using it against each other too much in elections essentially to get anything done, but talk to me really quickly about your district. I only have about a minute left, because it was a Republican district, a lot of Cuban Americans live there. However, it also has you know, a lot of you know, northeasterners who've moved to that area. So what do you think is the most important thing for them? What are they going to use to decide between the two of you?

utterances.speaker: SALAZAR
utterances.sentences: Well, the fact here is that I was born, raised, and I have worked on television in this town for 35 years. And that's why I'm sure the voters are going to prefer me over my opponent because Mrs. Shalala does not belong to the melting pot. See Miami is the ultimate melting pot in the United States and you need to be part of that social fiber. You need to be part of the ultimate melting pot in order to be able to represent them in the House of Representatives. I mean the name says it, the House of Representatives. And in reality, I am -- I am the person that could represent them the best because not only I speak the language but I they get me and I get them. You cannot come from outside and just want to help -- won a review of the representative from Miami.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: We're going to be watching it very closely on Tuesday night as all these returns come in. Thank you very much, Maria. Good to see you again.

utterances.speaker: SALAZAR
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Maria Salazar joining us from Florida tonight. So a big win for the White House with less than four days to go until the Midterms. You got these brand-new jobs numbers that show a very healthy economy as America heads to the polls.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: More American today, right now, this hour are working than ever before in the history of our country. How good is that? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So while there is a lot to argue about out there, it's pretty tough for either side to not like the economic numbers that came out today. Today's announcement included soaring jobs numbers of 250,000 jobs in October. Unemployment at 3.7, haven't been there since 1969, and wages for workers rising 3.1 percent. That's a big part of that number, that's a nine-year high. So here now Economist Art Laffer who served on President Ronald Reagan's Economic Policy Advisory Board and did a pretty good job there and then later as an economic adviser to president Trump's 2016 campaign. New book Trumponomics is out now. Art, good to see you tonight. ART LAFFER, ECONOMIC ADVISER TO PRESIDENT TRUMP'S 2016 CAMPAIGN: Good to see you, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You know, obviously those numbers look really good. Are you surprised this isn't more of a focus of the Midterm discussions?

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: Not really. I mean, I think people are well aware of the economics. It may not be the hyperactive conversation you want to have but I think they're very well aware. It's just amazing. And the changes in tax policy, Martha, have been incredible. I mean the tax bill was amazing. He got it through. It's just the foundation of his policies. And if you look at the deregulation, I mean amazing here as well. If you look at the monetary policy with Powell, I mean, he's doing a great job on that. And the trade is --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So why is the president keep yelling at it him, Art? Because the presidency you know, keeps saying that he shouldn't -- he doesn't like the suggestion that he's going to continue to raise interest rates and the market was down a little bit today. I mean, that's what -- that's what some market prognosticators are saying as you well know, that this is -- that we've had the high in this GDP. What do you say? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: Well I don't -- can't explain all of Donald Trump's conversations, to be honest with you. He does it -- he does it so forgive me, Martha --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: We need a longer show.

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: Yes, we need a longer show but Powell is doing a good job. And Trump is doing a great job on trade. I mean it's working progress right now but Xi and he are going to meet in Argentina and there's a very good chance we get good trade deals with China and we need China badly because without China, Martha, there is no Wal-Mart. And without Wal-Mart, there is no middle class or lower class prosperity. The U.S. needs China and China for goodness sakes really needs us and I think we're moving along on that very well. And then look at our GDP numbers growth. I mean, those are pretty astounding --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Let's put the GDP number up, guys.

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: Yes, and it's just great. You got to -- I don't know if you --

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So -- yes, we have it up. And so you know, obviously, very strong growth in the last two quarters in particular. What's your outlook for the next two? LAFFER Well, I hope it continues. I mean, we need about -- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Well, we all hope it continuous but you're the economists so what do you think it's going to do?

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: I think it's going to continue, how's that? I think we're going to have a very good prosperity for the next six or seven years. I think it's very much like the Reagan period, like the Kennedy period, and like the Clinton period, not Hillary, Bill. It's -- I think we're going to have a very strong economic growth for the next five or six years and we'll get back to the types of prosperity we really would need and want. And I think he's doing a great job on the economy and I'm an economist. I can't tell you about everything else but on the economy, he's as good as I've ever seen in the first term and he's not even halfway through it yet.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: All right, so in the 30 seconds I have left, what would be your one thing you would say to him, but don't do this, you know, because that would be problematic.

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: Don't raise taxes, don't increase regulations. But the thing I hope he does do is where we haven't succeeded which is government spending.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: We need to get control of government spending, entitlement programs, and government spending and I think that's what he is going to do in his next six years.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: All right. And so, Art, thank you very much. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Martha. It's great. I love your show by the way.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: I really do.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You can come back anytime.

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: Any time you want me I'm here.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: It's always good to see you. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: Greta to see you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: It's going to be very interesting to watch with this economy go. It's definitely not the top of my topic, but as you say, people feel it in what they're doing every day.

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: Only four days left.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And we'll see what happens when they walk into this voting booth.

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Art, thank you very much. Art Laffer joining us tonight. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: LAFFER
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, coming up this evening, what an interesting story Missouri is. Watching this race, Claire McCaskill going after a fellow Democrat for what she said about President Trump, and she is not alone as Democrats fight to win in red states. They have some very surprising messages out there. Former DNC chairwoman Donna Brazile is here with a message for them tonight on the Story, when we come back.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Some red state Democrats, if you listen closely, sound a bit like Trump supporters in this election. Among them, at risk Indiana Senator Joe Donnelly with this morning on the campaign trail.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The radical left wants to illuminate ICE.

utterances.speaker: SEN. JOE DONNELLY, (D) INDIANA
utterances.sentences: I support ICE, funding Trump's border wall.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: There you go. So West Virginia's Joe Manchin split with his party voting yes for Brett Kavanaugh, while Montana's Jon Tester tells the Hill that Democrats botched the debate on the new Supreme Court justice. Chris Stirewalt, Fox News politics editor joins us. What are you doing in New York, I came all the way to Washington to see you.

utterances.speaker: CHRIS STIREWALT, FOX NEWS DIGITAL POLITICS EDITOR
utterances.sentences: I must owe you money, I'm hiding out. I knew you are coming to town so I'm laying low up here.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Good move, my man. Good move. All right. So, you know, I mean, obviously they are running in red states but, you know, there's all this sort of idea that there are so many progressive candidates out there, but that is certainly not what these folks think is going to win the day for them, Chris.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: Well, look, I should start out and say, I think that these people are sincere, right. I think they are not saying things that they don't mean. But I do think this. Democrats by and large took the wrong lessons from Barack Obama's election and it was that they don't need white working-class voters anymore, right? When in fact, Barack Obama did really well with white, working-class voters. There were millions of Americans who voted both for Barack Obama and Donald Trump. There is a culturally conservative fiscally liberal streak that runs through a huge chunk of this electorate in states like these. This is the old new deal, Democratic coalition, and these were their grandchildren. And there are -- non-issues like immigration and others they are not liberal. They are actually quite conservative, and Democrats are coming around to having seen the electoral college consequences in 2016, and now looking at the Senate map in 2018. Some Democrats are understanding that they need these culturally conservative voters and they can't do it without them.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, it so interesting because the message, you know, certainly in the presidential candidates that seem to be lining up for 2020, it's completely the opposite of that. So, you know, when we obviously, when we see the results on Tuesday night, it's going to send a very big message out one way or the other to those future candidates. Won't it, Chris?

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: Well, it should, but it won't. It should if there were smart they would pay attention to what got results and how to win. Democrats have to have back the upper Midwest. They have to have that back if they want to be competitive, they've got to rebuild the blue wall and they can't just leave these voters follow. Now they are expecting a good night on Tuesday but it isn't whether they win or not, it's the lesson that they take from the victories that they do obtain and if they say, we are fine, we don't need to change anything, they are not paying attention.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: All right. I want to take a look at the Arizona race and an interesting back and forth. This is obviously this is a very tight race, Kyrsten Sinema and Martha McSally. Listen to this exchange.

utterances.speaker: KYRSTEN SINEMA, D, ARIZONA SENATE CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: You know in Arizona it's not new to have military deployment to the border to provide a support role for our customs and border agents who are down there. So, we wish them well and tell them to stay hydrated. REP. MARTHA MCSALLY, RARIZONA: Sorry, I didn't mean to laugh. Wow. Well, my message to them is, thank you for service and your sacrifice.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I mean, this is in many ways sort of the essence of the difference between these two candidates, Chris?

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: Well, yes, but. And I think the but here is, Kyrsten Sinema is an effective campaigner.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: And she has demonstrated that she has turned around substantially on these issues. But this is somebody who was an anti-war protester during the Iraq war, she was very left, left, left. But as she has represented a swing suburban district outside of Phoenix, what she's figured out is that doesn't play in Arizona. That's not what winds up with Arizona voters so she has recalibrated. And here is, she's doing the same smart thing that Claire McCaskill did in Missouri which is, you don't -- if Trump is trolling you on sending up a jillion troop to the border, you don't have to take the bait. You're not oblige to oppose him. You can say, yes, cool border security is good, it's fine, and take the issue away from Republicans and that's what smart Democrats do, they don't squeal.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And remind them to bring their water when they go to the border.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: And -- it's very dry out there. It's you who were just there, it's very dry.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's very dry out there. Chris, thank you so much, we'll be spending a lot of time together over the next few days. I look forward to it.

utterances.speaker: STIREWALT
utterances.sentences: See you soon.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So why is Nancy Pelosi taking heat from Michael Moore for saying her party is going to win it, and that she will be back? Former Democratic National Committee chair Donna Brazile joins me next.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL MOORE, FILMMAKER
utterances.sentences: A Democrat--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: -- who just automatically announced, we are going to win. And it's like, my God, that's what happened in 2016. REP. NANCY PELOSI, DCALIF., HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: Up until today, I would have said if the election were held today, we would win.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What happened today that change that?

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.sentences: Now what I'm saying is, we will win.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Nancy Pelosi saying she will win it, her bold assertion about winning back the house not sitting well with outspoken activist filmmaker Michael Moore who is worried that she is getting ahead of herself. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: A Democrat--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: -- who just automatically announced, we are going to win. And it's like, my God, that's what happened in 2016. Everybody was throwing the party for Hillary before the election. Don't think for a second that come Tuesday, they don't have every intention of holding onto the House and of the Senate. That is -- and they are good at what they do and you should respect the fact that they are able to get away with this.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: He saying, you got to fight until the very bitter end. Joining me now, Donna Brazile, former DNC chairs and co-author for the new book, "For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Politics." Donna, good to have you with us.

utterances.speaker: DONNA BRAZILE, FORMER CHAIR, DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL COMMITTEE
utterances.sentences: It's great to see you. Welcome to Washington, D.C.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Thank you, it's great to be here tonight.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So which camp are you in? Are you the optimist like Nancy Pelosi or the it's not over till it's over Michael Moore?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: I'm in both camps. Look, I come from the school that you have to work until the polls are closed across the country. I also believed that Nancy Pelosi has a real good gut instinct about what's happening out there, good quality candidates. She's been crisscrossing the country raising money but at the same time, Michael Moore is so right. You have to keep knocking on doors. We know that during midterm elections, Democrats tend not to turn out. We are more infrequent voters. Republicans treat every election like the World Series, Democrats like the World Cup.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, we heard the opposite for so long in this campaign, that Democrats were super fired up and that they were trying to get Republicans more fired up. But I want to play this interesting sound bite from Claire McCaskill who is obviously in a neck and neck race--

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sure.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: -- with Josh Hawley in Missouri right now. Watch this. SEN. CLAIRE MCCASKILL, DMO.: The crazy Democrats are people who walk in restaurants and scream in elected officials faces. The crazy Democrats are -- we have a state senator here in Missouri that actually advocated for the assassination of President Trump. That's a crazy Democrat.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: What do you think about that, Donna?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Well, there's a lot of people out there today that I would label as, let's just say, not civil. But the truth is, we have to tone it down. It's important that Democrats, Republicans and independents, that we find a way to tone down the rhetoric, it is hot out there. It is, as we call it in Louisiana, it's a nasty hot. But at the same time people are very passionate. They are passionate about healthcare, they are passionate about immigration. We need to allow people to speak their minds without confronting them. Look, I have Republican friends, I have Democratic friends and friends who are independents. And yet, you know what I want to do at the end of the day? I want to have a good glass of wine, I want to watch football and drink beer.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You know, that's the old way of Washington. It certainly doesn't feel like that anymore.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Yes. And by the way, are you wearing crimson red? Because you know I'm LSU. Are you not trying to send a signal here? Because go Tigers, go Tigers. And you see, we could talk about football without getting into a fight. I'm trying to put on my best shade of purple.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, you know, speaking of how nasty it gets, as you said.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: This is Maria Chappelle-Nadal who is a state senator. I mean, she went after Claire McCaskill. Look at this tweet that she put out there. "Claire McCaskill is desperate. She is a piece of S. You know what, instead of knowing what people of color are angered by this administration, she chooses to put us and our families in harm's way. If my family is harmed, blame it on Claire McCaskill. She deserves to lose. She is not a Democrat." Your thoughts?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: I don't know who this person is. I know who Claire McCaskill is.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: She is the state senator that Claire McCaskill is referring who called for the Assassination of President Trump--

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Well, come on.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: -- which by the way she said was a mistake.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Look, Michelle Obama was attacked. Barack Obama was attacked. The first lady has been attacked, Mrs. Trump, the president, OK? Cut it out, it's not what we do. These are people that we have elected to lead us, people that are serving as spouses. It is important that every--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, Hillary Clinton called for a no stability until after the election. Eric Holder said kick them in the knees. So you're against all that?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: I am against what the president of the United States says every day when he tweets. I'm against any elected officials using their job that we hired them to do to--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: But you are saying I want to be friends with everybody. So, are you also against Hillary Clinton calling for a no civility and Eric Holder saying kick them in the knees?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: You know, I don't want to sit here and name calling, what are we trying to prove by calling out Hillary and Eric? President Donald Trump--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I'm just saying be fair on all sides when somebody is out of line we have to call on all sides.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: I have -- I have been fair. But you know what, my job is, my job is a citizen because I'm no longer chair of the party, is to I go out there and to build hope. It's to inspire the next generation to vote. I'm worried that we have a lot of millennials who have not yet decided to vote. This is -- this election impacts their future, that's what I'm worried about.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Oprah was certainly doing a good job getting out in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: I love what she did yesterday, you know.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: But you know, I want to bring this up. Because the economy is doing so well.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And Jared Bernstein who was Joe Biden's former economic advisor tweeting today, "Pretty much everything you could want in a monthly jobs report. Payroll gains way up better than expected, nice pop in labor force participation, wage growth continues, finally beating inflation."

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You know, so he's very positive on the economy.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, you know, when you look at that, is that a difficult argument for Democrats to make in terms of, you know, rolling back some of these tax cuts, rolling back some of the regulatory changes that have helped to create this economy?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: The Democrats what they've been saying and I've looked at a lot of the ads. They want an economy that works for everyone. Whether you are making $100,000 per year, are your--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: This is what everybody is unemployment numbers are the lowest they've been in decades.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: -- are you getting paid. But you know, when Barack Obama was president Republicans had a hard time saying good news. I'd like to good news, good news. I wouldn't care if it's good news that come from a Democrat or Republican or independent. Good news. We want people to have jobs.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So you think President Trump has done a good job with the economy?

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: President Trump is not out there campaigning on the economy. He's campaigning as if people who are (Inaudible).

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: No, but that's not my question. My question is, do you think the president has done a good job with the economy so far.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: I think that the overall the structure of our economy is good. And while the White House is claiming credit just like Barack Obama claim credit for turning the economy around. Give credit where credit is due. We should not undermine people confidence in their country or the economy simply because they have a R or D behind their name. That's where I come down on all of this.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Donna Brazile, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: I want everybody to have jobs. I want to keep my job by the way.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Good to see you tonight. The book is "For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Politics."

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Martha.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Thanks for being here, Donna. Come back.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: I will.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Great having you here.

utterances.speaker: BRAZILE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So, it has been a while of high-profile celebrity endorsements for candidate across the country but does the average American care about celebrities and whether or not they will influence their vote? And it's Friday, it means it's time for our ladies' night panel here to weigh in, that's coming up next.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This midterm election, exercising your right to vote is as important as ever.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We are very close to election day, I just want to make sure that everyone knows how important it is for you to get out and vote early.

utterances.speaker: OPRAH WINFREY, TV HOST
utterances.sentences: Vote, vote!

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to do that. November 6th, please vote.

utterances.speaker: WINFREY
utterances.sentences: Vote.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So those are just some of the celebrities that are pushing voters to get involved in this election, some of them even going door-to- door to spread their message, but can Americans really be persuaded by the celebrities showing up at your door? It's a question even comedy central had a little bit of fun with.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: How will I know that I should vote.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: If celebrities don't tell me to?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Does Emily Stone think I should vote?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: What about John Krasinski?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Have you seen a quiet place?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, but that isn't what this is about right now.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's about celebrities.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Telling regular Americans that they have to vote.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Many millennial Americans like us don't know what we should do until celebrities tell us what to do.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Here now ladies' night. Jenny Beth Martin, Bre Payton, and Marie Harf. Ladies, so has there ever been a celebrity, anybody like that who sort of made you inspired to vote for someone?

utterances.speaker: JENNY BETH MARTIN, CO-FOUNDER, TEA PARTY PATRIOTS CITIZENS FUND
utterances.sentences: Not for me personally to vote for someone but I can imagine it might make an average voter, I would say not exactly average, because I live, breathe, and sleep politics.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: What do you think, Bre?

utterances.speaker: BRE PAYTON, STAFF WRITER, THE FEDERALIST
utterances.sentences: Yes. I'm going to say no. I want to say a hard pass. I think this is condescending and I think that we have proof of this. Taylor Swift came out and endorsed a Democratic candidate for Senate in Tennessee and it hasn't moved the needle at all. His Republican opponent is up by something about seven points according to Real Clear Politics average. Blackburn is leading that race over there. So, I think, you know, and this is supposed to like, melts everything, this is supposed to be a game-changer there and it wasn't.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAYTON
utterances.sentences: So, I think it doesn't--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You know, they are just sending -- first of all, if Will Ferrell showed up at my door I would just laugh hysterically. And I would - - if he gives me that serious message about voting, I'm just thinking that like, somewhere in there he's kidding actually, because I think he's hilarious.

utterances.speaker: PAYTON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: All politics aside.

utterances.speaker: PAYTON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: But Marie, you know, Oprah Winfrey was very powerful the other day.

utterances.speaker: MARIE HARF, FOX NEWS RADIO CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I mean, I could definitely see her having an impact on that race.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: And we saw in actually 2008 Oprah endorsing Barack Obama and then campaigning during the primaries, particularly in South Carolina, actually it appears to have made a big difference in that primary. People love Oprah. And she doesn't get out there and talk about the Democratic Party, she talks about the candidate and certain principles, so I actually think that Oprah in a race that is as close as it's going to be in Georgia might make a difference. And look, in Tennessee, I think it's still an open question. Tens of thousands of new voters registered in the 48 hours after Taylor Swift--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. But it was the last day -- I mean, it was the last day you could register right before she said it.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: That was -- sure, but we will see if -- she seems to have inspired--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: So we will see.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: -- a number of people to register. I think that a lot of these races, Martha, are going to be so close that even if celebrities only move the needle a little bit, a little but could actually matter.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely. I think there are going to be a lot of very tight races. I think we're going to see contested races.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I think a lot of races aren't going to be done on Tuesday night.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I agree.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Speaking of celebrities, Alec Baldwin got in trouble again in New York City. Now I'm sort of sympathetic because of someone steals your parking spot in New York City, it's like, you can't do that! The president came out today, there he is. He always looks like he wants to punch somebody, right? Pretty much always has that look on his face, but apparently, he punched a guy over a parking spot. The president was asked about it today and here's what he said.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Who was arrested?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Alec Baldwin. He punched someone out during a parking dispute.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I wish him luck.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: And Alec Baldwin had this to say when asked to comment on what happened. He said, "My comment is that my show aired Sunday at 10 p.m."

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: You now, it would be, seem to be a little bit sympathetic, he's got four kids under the age of five, and there's a parking space in New York. If he didn't have a history of this, but he has a history of punching people, photographers flight attendants.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: This could get ugly for him. He could be facing as much as a year in jail apparently, Bre.

utterances.speaker: PAYTON
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean. Sadly, this is kind of a cycle for him. Whenever he catches a break, that he does something like this. I think the timing is also kind of interesting. You hear just as the show that launched, then he's out here doing this. I mean, I'm just saying, I think it's interesting.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: You think, he's like I think I'm going to punch someone today because it will be good publicity?

utterances.speaker: PAYTON
utterances.sentences: No, not on punching. I just think that this tends to happen whenever he catches a big break. I don't know if it's a self-destructive tendency that he tends to have--

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: it could be.

utterances.speaker: PAYTON
utterances.sentences: -- words like, I'm doing well, got to mess it up. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I'm going to say, I am a hugely competitive parker in Washington, D.C., which isn't as bad as New York, but I have never punched someone. But like you, Martha, I can sympathize with people getting very upset about a parking spot. It is awful.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: Yes. I have to cut to a tiny bit of road rage at times.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: Me, too. I'm with you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: I can't help it. Somebody steals my parking spot, no, no!

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.sentences: I'm with you.

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.sentences: But time to punch anybody so far. Thanks, ladies. Great to see you all tonight. That is our Story on this Friday night. We'll see you again here on Monday which is election eve. Have a great weekend, everybody. Tucker Carlson coming up live next from D.C. Copy: Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
